Expectation1: Ensure compliance with safety and regulatory standards
Situation1: A routine audit is scheduled far ahead, leaving ample time to update documentation
Expectation2: Organize and lead religious education classes for children and adults
Situation2: The regular weekly religious education class for the parish's children is scheduled.
Story:
I stared at the calendar on my phone, the dates blurring together. As an engineer, I knew the upcoming audit was still weeks away, but my supervisor had just emailed, urging me to update all our safety documentation now, not later. “Get ahead of the curve,” he wrote, “so we’re not scrambling last minute.” I understood the importance—lives could depend on our compliance, and I prided myself on never cutting corners.

But tonight was also the weekly religious education class at the parish. As the priest, I was expected to lead the children, answer their questions, and guide them in faith. Parents trusted me to be there, to nurture their kids’ spiritual growth. I could already picture their faces, eager and expectant, waiting for me in the church hall.

My laptop pinged with another work reminder. My phone buzzed with a message from a parent: “Looking forward to seeing you tonight, Father.” I felt the pressure mounting, the weight of two worlds pulling me in opposite directions. I sat at my desk, heart pounding, torn between duty to my profession and my calling to my community, unsure which responsibility should come first.
